docs.lead_paragraph: Current cancer therapies attempt to find, test and treat specific genetic mutations that are shared by groups of patients. A new method is based on the idea that many cancers differ from patient to patient, and may have different genetic causes.

headline.seo: Cancer Therapy and Whole Genome Sequencing
headline.main: Conventional Cancer Therapy and Whole Genome Sequencing

docs.snippet: Current cancer therapies attempt to find, test and treat specific genetic mutations that are shared by groups of patients. A new method is based on the idea that many cancers differ from patient to patient, and may have different genetic causes.

docs.lead_paragraph: After years of treatment and two relapses of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, Dr. Lukas Wartman had exhausted all conventional approaches to his disease. A group at Washington University in St. Louis spent a month decoding his genetic information, a process called whole genome sequencing, in hopes of determining the genetic cause of his leukemia. The team found an overactive gene that was treatable with a drug for advanced kidney cancer. Here is how the process works.

headline.seo: Searching for a Cancer’s Vulnerable Target
headline.main: Searching for a Cancer’s Vulnerable Target
